thread.title: Morning Sports Update: Red Sox have draft pick closest to majors in Andrew Benintendi - Red Sox
thread.title_full: Morning Sports Update: Red Sox have draft pick closest to majors in Andrew Benintendi - Red Sox

author: boston.com
title: Morning Sports Update: Red Sox have draft pick closest to majors in Andrew Benintendi - Red Sox
text:
Andrew Benintendi ranked high in Baseball America’s poll of scouting directors, the Celtics’ rookies continue to look strong in preseason, and Brad Stevens has the experience needed for consideration for the Team USA head coach opening.
Red Sox prospect ranks best pure hitter, most ready for pros: “Benintendi landed as No. 1 in several categories, including quickest projected college player to reach the majors first, best pure hitter and best pro debut among college players. He was ranked second as best power hitter.” ( MassLive.com )
Tom Brady delivers short interview about (not) keeping footballs after touchdowns vs. Colts: “After Sunday’s 34-27 win in Indianapolis, Brady blew off NBC’s Michele Tafoya, then issued three terse answers when asked about keeping a souvenir football or two.” ( The Boston Globe )
Advertisement - Continue Reading Below Jump aboard the R.J. Hunter hype train: “R.J. Hunter could get used to this. After three years of being looked at by everybody, to do everything, all the time at Georgia State University, the Celtics rookie got a look he wasn’t used to seeing during last week’s exhibition game against the Brooklyn Nets.” ( The Providence Journal )
Could Brad Stevens be the next Team USA coach? “ While it’s clear that USA Basketball is in no rush to find a successor, Stevens possesses many of the qualities they’re likely in search of in a successor to Krzyzewski. For starters, they’ll likely want someone with international experience.” ( CSNNE.com )
Troy Tulowitzki hammers a three-run homer in Blue Jays 11-8 win over the Royals: The Blue Jays trail 1-2 in the series.
Your browser does not support iframes. Bill Belichick analyzes the failed fake punt play: “Well, I think the play was a version of the swinging gate play,” he said. “I don’t know exactly how it was supposed to work. That’s something you’d have to ask them about.” ( CSNNE.com )
Boston sports most significant injuries
Previous -- of -- Next Veterans Zdeno Chara and Dennis Seidenberg are both hobbled by injuries early on for the Boston Bruins. Chara is expected to return soon, while Seidenberg is sidelined eight weeks. Both are key to Bruins success, and the team and its fans hope the injuries are not serious. But sometimes they are. Here’s a look back at 22 sports injuries that broke Boston’s heart. Reuters / Brian Snyder Previous -- of -- Next Red Sox star Ted Williams fractured his elbow making a catch during the 1950 All-Star game. He missed 89 games and returned Sept. 15. The Sox finished in third place in the American League that season, losing out on the pennant by four games. AP File Photo Previous -- of -- Next Young Red Sox star Tony Canligliaro was hit by a pitch on his left cheekbone in 1967, and was carried off the field on a stretcher. He sustained a broken cheekbone and severe damage to his left retina. A year and a half later, Conigliaro made a remarkable return, but he was forced to retire early in the 1975 season because his eyesight had been permanently damaged. The Boston Globe Archives Previous -- of -- Next “Gentleman Jim” Lonborg, the ace of the Impossible Dream Red Sox in 1967, suffered a broken leg during a skiing accident after the season. After going 22-9 in 1967, with a league-best 246 strikeouts, he fell to 6-10 in 1968. Dan Goshtigian / The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next During the 1967-68 season, his second in the NHL, 19-year-old Bruins defenseman Bobby Orr was limited to 46 games because of a right knee injury. It became a career-long problem for Orr, who endured more than a dozen knee operations during his playing days and retired at age 30 in 1979. Frank O’Brien / The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next Celtics star forward John Havlicek suffered a right shoulder injury in Game 3 of the 1973 conference finals against the Knicks. New York won the series in seven games. Frank O’Brien / The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Red Sox rookie outfielder Jim Rice was not able to play in the 1975 ALCS or World Series because Tigers pitcher Vern Ruhle broke his left hand with a pitch during the last week of the regular season. The Red Sox lost to the Reds in the World Series. The Boston Globe Archives Previous -- of -- Next Patriots wide receiver Darryl Stingley collided head on with Raiders safety Jack Tatum in a 1978 preseason game. Stingley suffered two broken vertebrae and spent the rest of his life in a wheelchair. Stingley passed away in 2007. Frank O’Brien / The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Normand Leveille’s promising career ended Oct. 23, 1982, when the 19-year-old Bruins forward was hit into the boards during a game against the Canucks. After the period, he collapsed in the locker room due to a brain hemorrhage. Surgery saved his life, but he was in a coma for three weeks and never fully regained control of his speech. Jim Davis / The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next The first selection in the 1982 NHL Draft, Bruins defenseman Gord Kluzak tore ligaments in his left knee in 1984. After re-injuring his knee in 1986, he played in 66 regular season games and all 23 playoffs games in the Bruins run to the Stanley Cup Finals. But he would only play in 13 more games over the next two-plus seasons, and retired at the age of 27 after 11 knee surgeries. Bill Brett / The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next Celtics legend Larry Bird’s 1988-89 season ended after just six games when he had surgery to remove bone spurs from both heels. Chronic back problems caused him to miss 59 combined games during the 1990-91 and ‘91-92 seasons and eventually led to his retirement. Jim Wilson / The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Former BU hockey player Travis Roy was paralyzed just 11 seconds into his college hockey career in 1995 during a game against the University of North Dakota. The 20-year-old Roy slid head-first into the boards, cracking his fourth and fifth cervical vertebra. Stan Grossfeld / The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next A dirty hit by Penguins defenseman Ulf Samuelsson in the 1991 Wales Conference Finals caused Bruins forward Cam Neely to re-injure his knee. Neely developed chronic complications in the aftermath of the injury, leading to a degenerative hip condition that ended his career in 19966. Pat Greenhouse / The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Boston Bruins center Patrice Bergeron suffered season-ending concussions in 2007 and 2008. Fortunately, he has been relatively healthy through his prime years and continues to star for the Bruins today. AP / Elise Amendola Previous -- of -- Next Tom Brady’s 2008 season ended barely seven minutes after it began when the Chiefs’ Bernard Pollard crashed into the Patriots quarterback’s left knee just as he was stepping into a pass. Brady tore his ACL and the Patriots missed the playoffs. Jim Davis / The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next The Celtics’ defense of their 2008 championship was not to be after star forward and team leader Kevin Garnett missed the 2009 playoffs with a knee injury. Jared Wickerham / Getty Previous -- of -- Next Pro Bowl wide receiver Wes Welker blew out his left knee in Week 17 of the 2009 season, and the Patriots lost to the Baltimore Ravens in the first round of the playoffs. Jim Davis / The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Kendrick Perkins tore two ligaments in his right knee during Game 6 of the 2010 NBA Finals against the Lakers, and the Celtics lost Game 7 in Los Angeles without their starting center. Bill Greene / The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Bruins center Marc Savard sustained a serious concussion on a hit to the head from Pittsburgh’s Matt Cooke in March of 2010, but was able to return to the lineup for the playoffs that season. Savard suffered another concussion in January of 2011, and was shut down for the season, which ended with a Boston Bruins Stanley Cup victory. Savard has not played since due to post-concussion syndrome. AP / Keith Srakocic Previous -- of -- Next In the 2012 AFC divisional playoff game against the Texans, Patriots tight end Rob Gronkowski re-injured his broken arm, taking him out for the remainder of the playoffs. The Patriots lost the AFC Championship to Baltimore, Barry Chin / The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next In what would turn out to be the final year of the Kevin Garnett/Paul Pierce era, the Celtics lost All-Star point guard Rajon Rondo to a torn ACL in January of 2013. Boston bowed out to the New York Knicks in the first round of the playoffs. Barry Chin / The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Patriots defensive tackle Vince Wilfork tore his achilles tendon in Week 4 of the 2013 season and was placed on Injured Reserve. The Patriots fell to the Broncos in the AFC Championship Game. AP / David Goldman Previous -- of -- Next Gronkowski took a vicious low hit from the Browns’ T.J. Ward, tearing his ACL and MCL and ending his season in 2013. The Patriots lost the AFC Championship Game in Denver. AP / Steven Senne
